metadata.title: Activity and selectivity of CO hydrogenation catalyst prepared by supporting an Fe—Co bimetallic complex

KHOMENKO, A. KADUSHIN, N. KUTYREVA, YU. MAKSDMOV, V. MATVEEV Institute of Chemical Physics, Academy of Sciences, Moscow (U.S.S.R.) A. SLINKIN, E. FEDOROVSKAJA Institute of Organic Chemistry, Academy of Sciences, Moscow (U.S.S.R.) and V. KHANDOZHKO Institute of Element-organic Chemistry, Academy of Sciences, Moscow (U.S.S.R.) (Received December 1, 1988; accepted December 23, 1988) At the present time heterometallic complexes are widely used for preparation of supported multimetallic catalysts because of the possibility to control selectively of the CO hydrogenation reaction by varying structure, electronic porperties and metal particle size of the catalysts. For example, Schay and Guczi [I], Kaminsky et al. [2] and Iwasama et al. [3] for the Fe- Ru system, and Albanesi et al. [4] for the Ni Os system, have shown that the use of bimetallic complexes as the catalyst precursors resulted in both high activity and selectivity in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. Yermakov [5], Zwart and Snel [6] reviewed thoroughly the data for a great number of heterogenized clusters of Group VIII metals. Choplin et al. [7] observed bimetallic Fe Os and Fe- Ru species produced from bimetallic carbonyl complexes on the surface of MgO by high-resolution analytical electron microscopy; no such species could be obtained from a mixture of corres- ponding monometallic carbonyls. Similar results have been obtained by Ichikawa [8] for Rh Co and Rh Fe catalysts by EXAFS and Mossbauer spectroscopy. In the present work, we report on a bimetallic Fe Co/A^O^ catalyst showing nonadditive catalytic properties (activity in CO hydrogenation and selectivity for olefin production) with respect to each metal component. The catalyst was prepared by impregnation of7-Al203 with Cp(CO)2Fe- Co(CO)4 complex. The structural peculiarities of the catalysts were studied by in situ Mossbauer spectroscopy and magnetic susceptibility. Catalytic experiments were carried out in a flow microreactor, in which the A\^0^ support could be impregnated with a bimetallic complex solution in anaerobic conditions. The procedure is described in more detail in our 0304-5102/89/$3.60 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands L10 previous paper [9]. As a support, 7-alumina calcined at 550 C in a flow of air for 2 h and then in a flow of helium for 1 h (degree of dehydroxylation ca. 60%) was used. The bimetallic complex CpFe(CO)2 Co(CO)4 (I) was prepared by reaction of Cp(CO)2FeCl with [Co(MeOH)e] [(00)4] in methanol and was identified by IR spectroscopy and elemental analysis. Complexes [CpFe(CO)2]2 (II) and Ph2C2Co2(CO)6 (III) were synthesized and identified as in [10] and [II], respectively. The organometallic complexes were deposited on A1203 from pentane solutions at room temperature. After the solvent had been evaporated in a flow of inert gas at the same temperature, the reactor was heated to reaction temperature, and a flow of synthesis gas was then passed through the cata- lyst. Neither overheating of the reactor nor additional reduction of the catalyst in H2 at temperatures higher than reaction temperature occurred. The catalysts prepared as described maintained constant catalytic activity for at least 5 h. All catalytic data were obtained at atmospheric pressure, ratio H2:CO = 2:1, and volume velocity 150 h~1. The products were analyzed by gas chromatography. Mossbauer spectra of the iron-containing samples were recorded with an electrodynamic type MCA-2 spectrometer using "Fe embedded in a chromium matrix as a source. Magnetic susceptibilities were measured by the Faraday balance method. In Table 1 catalytic data for binuclear homo- and heterometallic Fe and Co complexes, as well as those for a mixture of carbonyls Co2(CO)g and Fe(CO)s are shown. Catalyst II, having an Fe Fe bond, is inactive at 220 C, and gives low conversion at 30% selectivity to olefins at 280 C. In contrast, catalyst III (Co Co bond) is active at 220 C, but selectivity to olefins is rather low. Catalyst I (Fe Co bond) starts to work at 220 C, showing activity similar to that of catalyst III and high selectivity to olefins. Increasing the reaction temperature to 280 C results in a slight decrease in activity with a simultaneous increase in selectivity. Further heating of the reactor to 340 C is accompanied by a drastic decrease in selectivity for olefin production. These data demonstrate that catalyst I, prepared from a bimetallic complex with an intermetallic Fe Co bond, is a hybrid catalyst exhibiting the best properties of catalysts II and III, obtained from monometallic complexes. It should be emphasized that catalyst IV, produced by impregnation of AlaOa with a mixture of Fe(CO)s and Co2(CO)s, differs markedly from catalyst I; it gives very high total CO conversion at very low selectivity to olefins (similar to catalyst VI, Table 1). Thus, the results of the present study confirm the idea proposed earlier that the use of bimetallic complexes as a starting material allow the design of catalysts with new properties. The basic data from Mossbauer spectroscopy and magnetic measure- ments are given in Tables 2 and 3. Measurements were made at all stages of Lll TABLE 1 Catalytic properties of Fe Co complexes supported on Al2C>3 (total metal content 1 wt.%) Cat. Complex React. 's iw / 2/ 0</ CO "-' MMftcn / "i /-\ /-s mtomn (~i(~ir<i-< 0000000 0000 '- *- ' ^^ ^^- 3 S33 <! ! <!<!<;<H ^^^^ S:S-S:~-^ ^^ ^ ~ ^ h^ ^^ h^ ^ ^ ^h^d^^h^ ^ ^ ^^ ( || ^ | L13 catalyst formation: (1) deposition of complexes on the surface of 'y-Al^O^ at room temperature; (2) activation in a flow of helium at 220 C; (3) after CO+H; reaction. As follows from Tables 2 and 3, the deposition of complexes on de- hydroxylated 7-Al2C>3 at room temperature leads to their partial interaction with the surface, causing a weak paramagnetism and the appearance in the Mossbauer spectrum of signals of oxidized iron forms Fe2"1" and Fe3"1". Complex II is essentially stable at room temperature. Heating of complexes at 220 C in a flow of inert gas for 2 h brings about a total decomposition of all complexes, along with increasing concen- trations of Fe and Co ion forms. At same time, in these conditions we ob- serve the dependence of magnetic susceptibility on the magnetic intensity, which indicates the formation of ferromagnetic particles. Especially great is the contribution of the ferromagnetic component for sample IV. As follows from Table 2, metallic iron appears in the Mossbauer spectra only in sample II. In this case, the appearance of ferromagnetism in samples I, III and IV probably results from the presence of metallic cobalt in the catalyst. During the CO+H; synthesis of catalysts II - IV there exist the II a-Fe, Ill Co, IV-Co monometallic phases, while on the surface of catalyst I intermetallic clusters of 3Fe:lCo are found. The presence of intermetallic clusters is confirmed by the data (Table 2) according to which the inner field value (H^ = 432 kOe) exceeds the value of the metallic iron field (for a-Fe at 300 K, H, = 330 kOe). As follows from [12], it is precisely the intermetallic cluster 0.75 Fe: 0.25 Co that is characterized by a maximum magnetic moment and, ac- cordingly, by the maximum value of the inner field on the nucleus. It is significant that, on the basis of Mossbauer spectroscopy, sample IV obtained from the mixture of Fe(CO)5 and Co2(CO)g does not contained metallic iron, although it exhibits strong ferromagnetism, apparently con- nected with the formation of metallic cobalt. This probably explains the similarity of catalytic properties of samples IV and VI (see Table 1). Contacting catalysts I and II with air (see Table 2, experiments I, II (A1203, air)) proves that the intermetallic cluster is a formation of finely dispersed particles easily oxidized in air, while the Fe in catalyst II exists in the form of rather large particles. Similar experiments with catalyst III, accompanied by measurements of magnetic susceptibility, have shown that ferromagnetic particles are easily transformed into paramagnetic ones by the oxidation of finely dispersed particles of metallic cobalt. The remainder of the transition metals in catalysts I - IV exists in the form of finely dispersed oxide phases dissolved in the "/-AlsOa subsurface layer. This is proved by the following data: the Fe2"1" parameters do not match the parameters of octahedral and tetrahedral iron in mixed Fe Al spinel [13]. Moreover, Fe24" ions are easily transformed into Fe3"^ when the samples come into contact with air (see Table 2, experiments I, II (Al^O^, air)). Measurements of Mossbauer spectra at 4.2 K (liquid helium) do not L14 lead to the appearance of a superfine structure, i.e. there is no exchange interaction between particles preserving their superparamagnetic properties. These might be either structures of the Fe O Al type or oxide clus- ters of less than 5 nm in diameter. Data contained in Tables 1 and 2 also show that catalysts I and II which are selective with respect to olefins are characterized by a higher 'Fe2+/'Fe3+ as compared with the less selective catalyst IV. Thermal treatment of catalysts I and II in flows of helium and of CO+H^ brings about the reduction of Fe3'1" to Fe2"1" while in case of catalyst IV the opposite process, oxidation of Fe2"1" to Fe3"1", is observed. Thus, the most active and selective catalyst for olefin synthesis from CO+H; among all of the catalysts studied in this work is characterized by the presence of an intermetallic Fe Co compound on the surface and high Fe^/Pe34" ratios in the subsurface layer of the ^-Al^O^ support. Our experi- mental data clearly show that such surface phases of transition metals can be obtained only when the catalyst is prepared from molecular complexes with an intermetallic bond.
